Topic.Title: Altera to use Intel fab for 14nm programmable chips

Message.Msg: TSM and ALTR will likely continue to collaborate on the 20nm FPGAs while INTC focuses on the 22nm process this year. However, with the Broadwell processor in volume production next year (2014), INTC will begin to shift its focus to 14nm.

Topic.Title: Altera to use Intel fab for 14nm programmable chips

Message.Msg: "ALTR will likely continue to collaborate on the 20nm FPGAs" Guaranteed....

Topic.Title: Altera to use Intel fab for 14nm programmable chips

Message.Msg: the same time intc was writing off fab space last cc, they announced that absolutely gigantic capital spending plan. Plug in some numbers, and intc is setting up enough fab space to do twice its current revenue. This deal won't be the last - look for intc to fab for everybody whose chips do not directly compete with intc. intc is going after all the foundries that fab chips that will compete with intc by trying to starve them out of biz/cash flow for future process development and spreading dev cost over multi-fabs.
great update.

Message.Title: NEW! nVidia publishes more Tegra 4 benchmarks vs Snapdragon 600/800......WOW!
Message.Msg: MUST SEE THE CHARTS OF COMPARISON in notebookcheckDOTnet/Nvidia-publishes-more-Tegra-4-benchmarks.88802.0.html ""Compared to the S600 as found on the HTC One and Asus PadFone Infinity, Nvidia promises more than twice the processing power in Specint2000 and SunSpider JavaScript benchmarks as well as overall browser loading times. Even Qualcomm's highly regarded Krait architecture was not quite able to deliver the same performance-per-MHz as Nvidia's Cortex-A15-driven APU."" ""Regardless, the upcoming Tegra 4 chip will be setting new standard upon launch for the mobile world. Nvidia boasts an impressive 57 FPS in GLBenchmark Egypt 2.5 (1080p offscreen), or about 20 percent higher than the Snapdragon S800. The Snapdragon S4 (as found on the Nexus 4 smartphone) was shown to be surpassed by an even wider margin. Notebookcheck will certainly update with further benchmarks of our own once mobile devices with the Tegra 4 APU are finally made available."" Note: The synthetic benchmarks comparisons are derived as follows: Tegra 4 scores: measured, optimization continuing Snapdragon 800 scores: based on Qualcomm marketing claims
better be good
very helpful

Topic.Title: NEW! nVidia publishes more Tegra 4 benchmarks vs Snapdragon 600/800......WOW!

Message.Msg: my impression is that NV never took Samsung exynos seriously - at least not as seriously as it does Snapdragon SoCs. Recent reports showed that Exynos ran into serious problems with heat and/or imcompatibility with LTE, thus (I am guessing) NV might consider it a moot point to make comparison with a half-dead competition product. Note: I think the Exynos 5 Octa's LTE issue may be related to the thermal one - in that integration or bundling with an LTE modem could seriously raise the TDP of the SoC. Just speculating from reading the internet chatter.

Message.Title: Less than 1% from the 200DMA
Message.Msg: Perhaps, just perhaps, we will finally see some Big PMs push us up through the 200DMA, today. IF the market continues to power higher, we might see a late surge to close over 12.68, where that average presently sits. We've already reclaimed the 9, 20 and 50DMA, yet the volume is still far lower than it's been over most of the last week. However, there have been several days where the volume was fairly anemic until 3-3:15, and then 2-3mm more shares have come in at the end of the day. As always, we'll know in the fullness of time. Max
One of those Big PMs JUST took a block of 143k shares at 12.60 that had been blocking the upward movement ALL day...this COULD get exciting!!! Volume is now picking up, quickly. M

Message.Title: QC in denial
Message.Msg: QC guys are now saying ..."You Thrashed us in performance and features ....so what!" Bunch of guys with a face full of blood - not just a bloody nose - saying I don't feel the pain :). Interesting how THREE SENIOR VPs from a Huge Company CAN ONLY WAVE THEIR HANDS IN RESPONSE TO THOROUGHLY DOCUMENTED ATTACKS BY NVIDIA! LAME QC marketing! LAME PRODUCTS! QC:Yeah we still have more wins than you - SURE will not be as many as before! :)

Right back at YOU, Schmenkle! And, yes, I do hope Mr. Hedgie doesn't knock us back down, later, but since my first post, the volume has gone from 6.6mm to 8.155mm, in 40 minutes. And, with all the announcements about the new benchmarks, etc, I think they're beginning to realize that NVDA just has too much going for them to keep the stock down, for much longer. Would love to get your expert take on some of the new initiatives and designs. You're one of the most knowledgeable people to ever post on here from a technological standpoint. Hope you're well and happy. Best, Max

Message.Title: Full disclosure/FYI about AMD new Board Director
Message.Msg: Since I had been out of town until late last night, I hadn't seen the news that had been posted about the newest appointment to the AMD BoD. Marty Edelman was just named to the Board of AMD, and I've known him for around 40 years, since he's married to my oldest/best friend's sister. While I haven't seen nor spoken to Marty in a year or two, and have yet to ask my best friend if he knows anything about this, I thought I'd just share what came to mind when I saw this. Marty is primarily a real estate lawyer who is uber-successful. However, I think he has also had some M&A experience, and that might be why he was brought in. AMD is SUCH a BAD company, as most of the people on this board already know, and perhaps they realize that their only chance, now, is to sell the company. I'm not saying they will or are even thinking about it, but it WOULD make some sense given their cash-burn, and that they are trailing INTC and NVDA in their two main markets. If this WERE to happen, I would "guess" that it would be QCOM who would buy them to try to play catch-up with NVDA on graphics, since the latest benchmarks are looking like many of us thought they would, i.e. NVDA is leap-frogging well ahead of them. So, IF this were to come to pass, I also think it would put NVDA "in play" or at least get the stock to a much higher level, as they would be the only major standalone graphics chip designer left. I am NOT suggesting that anyone trade on this thought, especially where it concerns buying AMD. Just some "food for thought". As always, we'll know in the fullness of time. Max

Message.Title: QCOM powered GS IV.....
Message.Msg: brightsideofnews..... brightsideofnewsdotcom/news/2013/2/27/exclusive-qualcomm-powered-samsung-galaxy-s4-gt-i9500-performance-revealed.aspx

My take ? ha ha, you sure you don't have me confused for someone else? I think NVDA is doing what they said they would. The mobile market is the most lucrative and growing semiconductor market as evidenced by QCOM surpassing INTC in marketcap. NVDA said they wanted to be a player in that space, and while they may be having a rough ride turning the ship, it looks like they are on the right track with Tegra, esp the integrated modem part. Long term that's what they need to compete. Short term there are still a lot of doubters (I have had mine, believe me). The market does not want single source anything. AAPL and Samsung I think will retain their pieces, but the rest of the pie is going to grow a lot bigger. China is the best example. Low cost smart phone parts like tegra4ti will do very well there over the next few years. PCs are not going away any time soon. Gamers still like the open platform, and content developers will still need capable parts like Quadro. NVDA's PC business will just improve (higher margin) with AMD sucking wind. (I can't see how INTC or MSFT ever regains their glory, the world has moved on). And I think Project Shield is a very interesting. NVDA is supporting an open standard, a strategy that has made a lot of tech companies very successful starting with IBM in the 1980s. It is a bold step, but they had to do something different to provide a more capable hand held platform that is not closed. It's gotta be driving sony and nintendo nuts. There is nothing on the market like Shield and I think it's the first of many flavors that will come. Haven't heard pricing yet, but if this is a few hundred dollars it's a real winner in my estimation. If you think about it, NVDA is starting to own all pieces of the pipe from server to extended client. That will give unusual advantage and differentiation. Its a very interesting strategy and they are uniquely positioned to bring all the pieces together (including the most important element, the software stack). I am still bullish. When we see a few more T4 and T4i design wins lined up the world is going to look way different, and $12 will be a distant memory. Near term, I think the company could stand some relationship repair. IR needs to get off their #$%$ and tell their story better. and Jensen needs to drop trou and cement those fall mobile design wins now. But what do I know? cheers

Topic.Title: QC Dissing - #$%$ on Competition as usual

Message.Msg: A QC SVP of product management, told a Verge editor that Snapdragon 800 would "easily" beat Tegra 4 when it is released - the guy refuted benchmark results without offering any information to back up his act. A very lame defense. In the course of the interview, a few interesting tidbits were revealed about the S800: --S800 will be sampling in the NEXT quarter, meaning Q2. I had thought that sampling was ongoing now...this could mean that S800 is further down the road than T4, and things are finalized just yet. --QC claims 50 design wins in the works -- hey, how can you claim design wins before sampling is done? - yet NONE has been announced. Perhaps this information could offer a lesson or two to those who expressed disappointment that too few product announcements have been made. The telco industry has a much longer timeline for product development in comparison with other tech sectors. dailytechDOTcom/Qualcomm+Claims+NVIDIA+Tegra+4+Will+be+Easily+Beat+by+Snapdragon+800/article30002.htm

tegra4 is a non starter.. All that performance BS, is just Jensun stroking himself. Without LTE/Comm chip, its dead in the water. Nvidia-icera modems don't have a single phone company certifying it yet.
Do you see a reason why the Icera modems wouldn't be certified? and I assuming you mean the I500 chip, because in the past Nvidia-Icera chips have been certified by networks.
Yes - a lot of downward pressure. You should sell before it goes down further.

Topic.Title: QC Dissing - #$%$ on Competition as usual

Message.Msg: It might have something to do with the A15 power problem in phones. anandtechDOTcom/show/6787/nvidia-tegra-4-architecture-deep-dive-plus-tegra-4i-phoenix-hands-on NVIDIA Tegra 4 Architecture Deep Dive, Plus Tegra 4i, Icera i500 & Phoenix Hands On by Anand Lal Shimpi & Brian Klug "Samsung recently disclosed details about its Cortex A15 implementation compared to the Cortex A7, a similarly performing but more power efficient alternative to the A9. In its ISSCC paper on the topic Samsung noted that the Cortex A15 offered up to 3x the performance of the Cortex A7, at 4x the area and 6x the power consumption. It’s a tremendous performance advantage for sure, but it comes at a great cost to area and power consumption. The area side isn’t as important as NVIDIA has to eat that cost, but power consumption is a valid concern."

Topic.Title: QC Dissing - #$%$ on Competition as usual
